name: HP HyperX Alloy Core RGB Wired Gaming Keyboard
comments: Great looking RGB and key stabilizers for $50CAD. Audio control buttons are nice to have. Doesn’t sound terrible either and decent build quality with extendable back legs.
RGB keys look ugly. And it's weird for ME to type
Really all I needed. Looks really cool and haven't had any issues with it. If you aren't looking for anything crazy or special, just get this keyboard and call it a day.

I love the three buttons at the top, but sad there's no programmable RGB (there's a few set buttons that change your RGB, but you have no choice on your own.) Love the button that locks the windows-key so you can't press it. Has saved my *** multiple times now. Would probably upgrade to a mechanical keyboard after this, as the keys are quite high and my hands are not that big, meaning that I have to really reach and press down to press the keys, which causes discomfort in my wrists. Also a bit of input delay, regrettably, which affects me probably the most.
Feels great while gaming and typing. Some keys are clickier than others. You don't need a hundred dollar keyboard, just get this. RGB options look great even though they're limited.
Good keyboard works great. RGB options are limited.
Good for gaming and typing. It performs well and the RGB looks good.
Really nice keyboard. I didn't want anything mechanical, so this works well. Pretty quiet and has a lot of room. The media control and RGB selections are nice
Cheap keyboard ended up surpassing my expectations but the media controls are awesome. RGB is so-so. Kinda wanna see what mechanical feels like tho
Haven’t decided on which mechanical keyboard to get so I picked this up as a back up and really like it so far. Works great.

name: RK Royal Kludge RK61 Bluetooth/Wireless/Wired Mini Keyboard
comments: I absolutely love this keyboard. The blue switches sound great and the key caps just allow your fingers to glide across the keys. The RGBs, or really just Bs, looks great and has like, 20 different modes of RGB. Would give it 10 stars if possible
It's the color I wanted, and a good price, but still getting used to the smaller keyboard.
Cool little keyboard, but lacks some function. You need to hit Fn and CTRL to get the functions working.
I wish that the cabel connection was on the left-top side instead on the top-left side if that makes sense. I also can't seem to change the backlight color without the software.

name: Redragon K552 Wired Gaming Keyboard
comments: Fits my needs, although I kind of wish it was a bit smaller.

Great value for the money, my only gripe is that for some of the reactive rgb modes, when typing the processor can seemingly get overwhelmed and stop displaying new inputs briefly, still a beautiful and satisfying keyboard.

Pleasantly surprised about Redragon products, very nice and cheap mechanical keyboard and has a great click with red switches. Can't say much for the long term use as I only started with it but I don't see a point overpaying for branded mechanical keyboards if you can get this for €35 on Aliexpress.
Well done Redragon!
I have the white version and it's a good value keyboard.
Has an awful springy sound after every keypress. But it works, and is very loud and clicky.

The keyboard itself is good, great responsiveness and looks nice.
There are 2 reasons why I’m giving it 3 stars and this is more based on my personal experience.
It is very loud, so using it at night when my flatmates are sleeping and when I lived with my parents was a disturbance.
2 It’s ten-keyless, now this wasn’t an issue when I first purchased it but now I find that having a NUMPAD would be beneficial considering the games that I play.
Nothing to take away from the keyboard though, you get what you pay for.

I got this Keyboard off of amazon for dirt cheap a few years ago. Why did I get blue switches you ask? Because I hate myself of course. My two problems for this keyboard. 1 - There's no software to control the RGB. 2 - Whenever you press a key theres this sort of metallic springy sound. It's nothing bad and it's pretty faint, but it's still there. I'm pretty sure this keyboard has a metal backplate, so it's probably that.

I personally used this keyboard for around 3 years (from 2016 to 2019) and the general consensus I can give is that it is a REALLY good, albeit loud, gaming keyboard. The only flaw I can really see in it is that it's tenkey-less, but for both me and the cousin this keyboard went to, that usually isn't a problem. It's now been serving him for almost the same amount of time that I used it (~2 years for him so far, as of October 20, 2022,) and it seems that the decision to give it to him was very much worth it. 5 stars!
This is my old keyboard. Converted me to mechanical.
great bang for the buck. rgb is wonderful but no audio control means i had to bind it to the side mouse buttons

name: Asus ROG Azoth Extreme RGB Bluetooth/Wireless/Wired Gaming Keyboard
Razer Huntsman Mini RGB Wired Mini Keyboard
comments: Fast
Very lovely. Cute and quiet.
I am a huge fan of 60% keyboards. This one is excellent. It has great RGB customization, while retaining a small form factor.
Purchased this to go with my Gamepad Razer Mercury theme.
sounds nice, good

Good keyboard if u like loud clicky keyboard, dont really notice how loud it is until ur friends hear it in the mic. If thats not ur style there is a less clicky version. Don't download synalse for the love of God. It always is running in the background and opens every start. Sometimes I have to unplug the keyboard so my taskbar will load in. The actual keyboard itself is really good just some software issues
Amazing keyboard. Lights are great along with build quality. the cable coming off the back of the keyboard is done beautifully as well.
The keyboard is great but I've been noticing that the keys or the switches (idk) are kinda sticking. Like when I move to the right then I lift my finger and I'm still moving to the right.

This keyboard is a 10/10. If you want a small clean looking, beautiful-sounding keyboard, buy the Huntsman Mini 1000%. The RGB flow looks super clean with the mercury color, I was thinking on getting the black one to keep my setup neutral, but I do not regret buying the white one, it really makes things stick out.

name: Corsair K70 RGB PRO Wired Gaming Keyboard
comments: Went from a K55 to this keyboard and while I kinda miss the macros on the K55, the Cherry MX Red switches are no joke, it leads to some fast typing and fast response time for gaming.

My (hopefully) endgame keyboard. The Speed Silver switches' actuation are very light, requiring almost a thought to activate, which I very much enjoy for gaming. Typing takes a little getting used to, some mistakes may be made, but overall worth it.
It's a good keyboard so far, about three and a half months old, no issues and I could use a rainbow wave prest that looks nice and I don't have to use iCue.

I really like this keyboard, the buttons are nice to use and there are a few features I love. Having media keys and a swivel volume rocker is pretty convinient and being able to simply unplug the type-c connector and move it out the way for more space to do other work is extremely handy. It surprised me that the key switches don't have much protection against accidental spills, and so my soul left my body when I spilled coffee on it. However, I was able to unplug it instantly and let dry for a while before cleaning it and now using it again as if nothing happened. I'll never have a keyboard without an easily removable cable ever again, its a staple feature!
pricey but very solid keyboard.
Clickity clackity.

I am most conflicted about this keyboard out of the parts of my built. on one hand it is very well built. the RGB looks nice, the media controls are cool, and it feels nice, and the double-shot PBT kecaps feel very nice, on the other hand however, i dont think i am the biggest fan of the linear switches, inb gaming they are quite nice and fine, but in typing i really dont like them, the easyness to push down combined with the wobblieness of the keysaps causes me to click another button by accident constantly, i have had to go back and delete so many times while writing this, i would not be suprised if the backspace key is the first to go, it will probably be better as i get more used to it, but it is still annoying, and this goes without mentioning the noise, there is a very loud and noticable metallic twang noise., that seems to have only gotten louder with time, overall for a first mechanical keyboard it is not bad. but i will propably get something rather differet next time.
I wish this had a wireless option, but it's a great keyboard. Nice and heavy construction, and they use Cherry switches.

I upgraded from a Red Dragon keyboard and mouse combo that I bought off of Amazon which served me well for the last few years. I decided with my new gaming rig that I would purchase higher quality and boy does this keyboard not disappoint.
PROS: First thing I notice is that it is very sturdy and a bit heavy compared to what I am used to. The keys themselves when typing have a nice crisp click and the RGB effects from the Corsair software add a nice touch to the set up. When used for gaming, if feels great. I do also like the volume scroller which makes it easier for me to control the volume when in games.
CONS: I will say that this is probably the only downside to the keyboard is the clicking when typing, but this does not bother me at all. It also is a bit costly for those on a budget.
OVERALL: This is a high quality build, though expensive I would say you are getting what you pay for. Highly recommended for anyone looking for a quality product with RGB.

The Corsair K70 is a pretty good keyboard. It feels nice, especially with the PBT keycaps. I will say that the noise generated from typing on it is not as nice. The overall sound is okay, but there is a hollow metallic twang that you can barely hear when typing, and its a bit irritating. When gaming or actively working its not very noticeable, especially with headphones on, but I wouldn’t type an essay on it thats for sure. In hindsight, I would have probably gotten a nice Keychron mechanical keyboard, possibly a Q6. I hate to say it but I do like iCue, its grown on me and I like all the easily programmable features included, especially the macros.

name: Logitech G19 Wired Standard Keyboard

specs.Features:
Tiltable, color GamePanel LCD: The (320 x 240) display shows unprecedented levels of information—both in- and out-of-game—including game stats, system information, VOIP communication data, video playback, image slideshows, and many other items.
User-selectable backlit characters: Personalize the keyboard to better fit with the rest of your computer and gaming equipment, and easily locate keys—even in the dark.
Twelve fully programmable G-keys with three macros per key: Program up to 36 single keypresses or complex macros; use the MR key to record new macros on-the-fly.
Multi-key input: Use up to five keys at once to perform multiple complex actions.
Game/desktop mode: Disable the Windows/Context Menu keys so they won’t interrupt your game if pressed accidentally.
Two powered Hi-Speed USB 2.0 ports: Transfer data to and from peripherals—such as MP3 players and flash drives—while also charging battery-powered devices.
Intelligent cable management: Keep mouse, headset, and other cords out of the way by routing them through channels on the underside of the keyboard.
Instant media access: Use the convenient one-touch controls for volume and media playback.

comments: Still luv this keyboard.

name: Logitech K120 Wired Standard Keyboard

specs.Features:
Comfortable, quiet typing
Thin profile
Sturdy, adjustable tilt legs
Easy-to-read keys
Curved space bar
Spill-resistant design
Durable keys
Plug-and-play USB connection
Logitech reliability

comments: Sounds kinda mechanical but not the best.(got it for free so I ain't complaining)
Basic keyboard. I don't really know what else to say besides the fact that it's a keyboard and doesn't look stupid like those "gaming keyboards" do. Feels quality and comes at a very low price.
Better than my IBM model M
Excellent price-value ratio.
It's a good, simple, membrane, plastic keyboard. It just does the job well. Nothing else to say about it, at all.
Ran out at best buy but had these shimmers of gold
Basic and cheap, lasted me two years of heavy usage before the plastic leg snapped off.
It's a keyboard. It's Logitech. It's basic. It's fine.
It's a keyboard. Feels high quality, and buttons are sturdy and satisfying to use.
Cheap noisy keyboard, works as intended. Quiets down on a desk mat

name: Razer Huntsman Mini RGB Wired Mini Keyboard
comments: Got to replace my previous keyboard which I wasn't a huge fan of. This one has pretty RGB and syncs with Signal RGB which is nice.
This is a very nice sounding keyboard and it works for all the things I need it for, and the RGB software I use makes it look super nice
Good looking keyboard.
Got to replace my previous keyboard which I wasn't a huge fan of. This one has pretty RGB and syncs with Signal RGB which is nice.
Really good feel with the optical red switches and pbt keycaps, but the software is kinda annoying sometimes and its hard to get used to the 60% layout

I was fortunate enough to buy this off a friend for $50 which is a good deal because I personally think this is overpriced. I haven't used any other mechanical keyboards so I have nothing to compare it to, but the keycaps feel very cheap and. Razer software is of course pretty easy to use as well. Overall pretty good keyboard if you can get it for a good price

I like it. I got it because I had a small desk at the time.
The only issue I have is, it's way too easy to press the keys. You could breathe on it and they would activate. So, if you want fast activation, here you go.

name: RK Royal Kludge RK61 Bluetooth/Wireless/Wired Mini Keyboard
comments: Good keyboard, but some of the shortcuts are difficult to get used to and the cable broke less than a week into having it so now I'm -1 other USB cable. Pretty good keyboard, I like it!
yahh
It’s ok there’s better but good budget keyboard

The mechanical switches that are included sound good, and the software allows for easy customization of the the RGB. The Version I have is wired only, but the layout of the keyboard is the same. It being a 61 key keyboard means it's harder to use some of the keys mid game, but it works for what I need.

name: Microsoft WTA-00001 Wireless Ergonomic Keyboard With Laser Mouse

specs.Features:
Mouse & Keyboard
2.4 GHz Wireless Technology
The 2.4 GHz wireless USB mini-transceiver connects wirelessly right out of the box with virtually no interference, and up to 30 feet of wireless range.
Mouse
Advanced Ergonomic Design
Advanced design promotes a more natural hand, wrist, and forearm position for greater comfort.
Revolutionary Ergonomic Design
Soft-touch materials and an ergonomic design fit your hand as naturally as a handshake.
High Definition Laser Technology
Microsoft High Definition Laser Mouse products are more precise, more responsive, and deliver smoother tracking.
4-Way Scrolling
Scroll four ways for greater efficiency and comfort with Tilt Wheel Technology.
Instant Viewer
Too many open items on your desktop? Click the scroll wheel button to instantly display your open windows, then point and click to select.
Magnifier
Point and click to enlarge and edit details using the Magnifier*.
6 months battery life
Long battery life helps ensure that you aren’t stuck without your important tools when you need them.
Battery Life Indicator
You won't get caught with a dead battery—the Battery Status LED Indicator glows red when the battery is running low.
Customizable Buttons
Get quick access to the media, programs, and files you use most often with customizable buttons.
Five Customizable Buttons
This mouse has five buttons that can be programmed to do a variety of functions.
Keyboard
Comfort Curve Design
Zoom
Improved Number Pad
Internet Hot Keys
E-mail and Internet Hot Keys
"My Favorites" hot keys
Integrated Palm Rest
Cutting-Edge Design

name: Razer Huntsman V3 Pro RGB Wired Gaming Keyboard
comments: Awesome keyboard. Switches are buttery smooth, as an analog switch should be.

name: SteelSeries Apex 3 TKL RGB Wired Gaming Keyboard
comments: Very nice and clicky

This was my first gaming keyboard from a major brand. I have had gaming keyboards in the past, but they were all from knockoff brands. It is also my first 75% TKL keyboard. For what it is, it's expensive, but the build quality is really good and it's also insanely quiet. The 75% TKL design is also perfect for my needs as I don't need any of that numberpad BS. I originally got it for my laptop to use as an external keyboard, but honestly after seeing how good the build quality is, I'm actually going to use it in my main setup. I used it to write this review and honestly it also feels really nice to type on. However the keys feel a bit spongy so I might switch back to my mechanical keyboard, but I wanted to try it out first.
First gaming keyboard. Not mechanical or per rgb, but has a good feel and is quiet enough.
Feels amazing.

Very nice RGB keyboard. The keys are nice and quiet compared to other models and brands which is what I was looking for. Was bought on offer as I think £50 for it is a bit steep. No complaint about it from me.

Pretty decent budget keyboard. I needed the TKL size as some of the programs/games I use have controls on the side. Rgb customization is there for those who need it, I just have it set to one color. Yes, the keyboard is not mechanical, but being my first gaming keyboard, it's OK. The keys feel a little soft when pressing, so perhaps later down the line I will look into a proper mechanical keyboard. But for now, gaming and typing is fairly comfortable.
Gets the job done for now, very quiet.
Good cheap keyboard, really silent and reactive

name: Logitech G PRO RGB Wired Gaming Keyboard
comments: Never Buying a Different Keyboard as long as I live
I love this keyboard I going be sad when it’s keys start to breaks down for repeated keystrokes
I've had this keyboard for 2 years it has only had 1 issue 3 of the key caps smudged. Update: bought another one of these keyboards because its reliable, gave the old one to a friend.
I got it kind of overpriced. Get it for 100$ and it's a steal. Tbh, I think 120$ wasn't actually overpriced, and the 80$ amazon version was a scam.
I've used many keyboards before and this is one of the better prebuilt keyboards out there and it's only 70 (On sale). Also links with all my other Logitech gear

I've had a number of keyboards over the years on office computers and this one feel great to use and work with. I love all of the added features that are provided to you through the GHub software as well, and given that I have quite a few Logitech parts on hand, I decided to compliment them with a keyboard.
-Love the keyboard! -It's not too loud or quiet! - Got it for $60 and haven't looked back!
Keycap paint comes off easy and space bar has a bad stabilizer. Does look very nice though
Great keyboard but weird key sizes, hence the black space bar.

Love it, you can change the switches, but for me blue clicky (which are the ones included) are nice.
used to have a 10 key design but prefer TKL for all that extra mouse real estate.

name: SteelSeries Apex Pro TKL (2023) RGB Wired/Bluetooth/Wireless Gaming Keyboard
Logitech PRO X RGB Bluetooth/Wireless/Wired/Wired Gaming Keyboard
comments: First time I've gone wireless on a gaming keyboard and I've loved it so far. The keys sound and feel lovely.
Great battery Life!

name: Razer BlackWidow V4 Pro RGB Wired Gaming Keyboard
comments: Sounds and feels amazing.

I absolutely love razer products. I know a lot of people hate on them because of the price. Or say that they go bad. But I have always used razer and their products last me YEARS. I own 6 different razer products all currently in use.

name: Redragon K582 SURARA RGB Wired Gaming Keyboard
comments: It's decent, I like the flashy colors. Some of the keys are temperamental due to high rate of use, dropping out when typing or moving around in a game, which might be more manageable if I knew how to maintain a keyboard...also it has hot swappable Outemu red switches, and these are the first mechanical key switches I've had. I think in the future I'm going to want to get browns, because the smooth travel makes it really vague, and really easy to press or hold down a key I don't want to be holding down just because my finger is resting on it. If that happens I want some tactile response.
Stabilizers are terrible, switches sound pretty good though. RGB is also pretty good and even throughout the board.

This keyboard is ok, but I would avoid getting it. I've had it for a few months now and already some keys will intermittently stop working for periods from 5 minutes to a couple of days. I would actually recommend getting the GK61, but it is a 60% keyboard while this is full sized.
Loads of RGB patterns and options on this keyboard and it’s also a mechanical as well. Lots of value for the price.

I love this keyboard. Has Outemu Red switches (just a much cheaper version of Cherry reds honestly you can do your own switch research) and the RGB even left at standard is pretty slick. I wanted to have the 10key (I still use it at least) and wired so this was the right choice for me.

I honestly love this keyboard. Looks really clean and has good weight. Lights behind the keys look good and have a lot of options for different patterns and modes. The keys are pretty loud and clicky which some people may find annoying but I personally like the sound they make. Coming from a laptop, it took me a little while to get used to the size and shape of the keys but overall not a big deal. Great keyboard for only $40

I really like this keyboard. It is on the quieter side for a relatively inexpensive mechanical, but I do wish it was just a tad quieter.
After a few months of use, on of my switches started flaking out. Customer service helped me figure out how to use the included tools and an included extra switch to fix it. Great service!
It's cheap, it's mechanical, it's per key rgb. Only gave it 4 stars because it's a bit difficult to find the RGB software for the keyboard on the website but other than that it's great.
Vibrant, quiet, durable. Great budget mechanical!

Very epic「GAMING」keyboard. Full RGB, clicky mechanical keys (like cherry mx red, but they are not cherries), lots of on-board customization too, so you don't need to use the app it has online (which I don't think you should, since it probably is riddled with viruses, so I recommend you don't use it, but you could try if you like). Lots of media keys (not dedicated, they are tied to function keys). All of that under $50! It's good, I recommend it.

name: HP USB Keyboard Wired Standard Keyboard
comments: Just some generic keyboard, but it gets the job done. Also, it works decently for typing.
Just recently upgraded away from this thing since it is very bog-standard, adios, my resilient friend!

I have a parrot (sulfur crested cockatoo) and the keys don't break when she beaks/pecks them off: 10/10 durability, they just click back on fine! A little annoying to keep clean, with the keys being so open and all, and a key or two gets a tiny bit stuck-ish with long use, but overall, I actually surprisingly like this keyboard, would never think of getting a mechanical one if I could just get a higher end, easier to keep tidy one like this.

name: Corsair K55 RGB PRO Wired Gaming Keyboard
comments: This keyboard is exactly as advertised. I use the 6 left buttons for my streams using the elgato software. The lighting is easy to setup using iCUE, with several options available.

Sadly, after 3 great years, the K55 has been retired for a Razer Huntsman Mini V3 that showed up at our doorstep for no reason. The K55 was such a nice keyboard for the price point. I got the XT model for my friend's birthday 3 years ago and he still uses his.

A common membrane keyboard which at first feels strange but a good strange haha, the illumination is quite nice and shines bright enough to distinguish each key, if it had illumination on the multimedia buttons I would give it 5 stars.
for this price you could get a better mechanical keyboard.

chose it because it was the cheapest and im not disappointed. my favorite part is the volume and play/pause/skip buttons on the top right. the only downside is the individual keys arent lit up but it doesnt affect me, especially because of the price
A good keyboard that gets its job done with flying colors.

Exactly what I was looking for. If you hate mechanical keyboards as much as I do, this keyboard will probably be perfect for you. I find "media keys" (pause, play, next,... + volume keys) especially useful. Other shortcuts available if you need them. Work with iCUE, so great if you own other Corsair products. If you care about RGB though, you'd probably want to give 10 bucks more to get the XT version. The difference? Each keys on the XT version has its own light, while on this version, RGB is made in areas. It clearly looks less good than the XT, but I personally don't really care about RGB.
RGB Keyboard. One caveat is that the lights stay on after you shut down your computer. I would be fine if it was one color but it flickers all sorts of colors

Good RGB and the keys feel good, but definitely not the highest quality since it's a membrane keyboard. Wrist rest is good but wish the keyboard was a bit shorter and the wrist rest provided a bit more support. Overall a good purchase. Plus it sounds nice too!

good membrane keyboard, could've had the PRO XT one for 5 euro more but i didn't know of its existance before i ordered it.
its good to know it's resistant to dust and water but i think those technologies are also incorporated into the higher-end keyboards that corsair makes, they just dont market them there because they are high-end.

name: Corsair K65 PLUS RGB Wired/Wireless Gaming Keyboard
comments: I think it's an extraordinary keyboard for someone at the beginning of the hobby with mechanical keyboards, especially if you find it on offer.

Now this. This is what I wanted to review.
This keyboard is amazing, it's a prebuilt computer (obviously), pre lubed, silent yet amazing corsair red switches and pretty good keycaps.
Now since this is a new keyboard, not too new but yk, I would expect them to address the off set lables on some letters, doesn't annoy me but you never know, I like to use it without rgb but even then the rgb looks amazing and it super clear, the rgb doesn't go thru the keycaps which for me is a win but for some it may not be. Actually good shortcuts as well, even if I'll never use them

name: Razer Huntsman V3 Pro Mini RGB Wired Mini Keyboard
comments: I bought a mousepad on Amazon and they delivered... This? Best. Accidental. Delivery. Ever. A joy to use, very fast.

name: SteelSeries Apex Pro RGB Wired Gaming Keyboard
comments: This keyboard far exceeded my expectations. I got it for the adjustable actuation points and was greeted with a very user friendly software, hotkey setups, and a newer feature of rapid speed and rapid tap keys (which are just fancy gamer things I'd recommend just looking up).
Satisfying sound and satisfying feel!
Very good keyboard, I got it as a replacement for my M750, feels a lot nicer, also the OLED screen and USB passthrough are nice features. Definitely pricey though.
Amazing quiet keyboard, love the wrist rest, THE SOFTWARE IS CRAZY.
My favorite keyboard.
This is an overkill featured keyboard. I love it!

The omnipoint switches and OLED display are overrated gimmicks but the per key RGB and all round "keyboardness" is excellent. also USB pass through is such an underrated feature. I can plug my mouse for 0 latency gaming/charging or charge my headphones while at my desk, and the wire I use came with the mouse (its very lightweight) so sometimes I forget my headphones are plugged into my keyboard and get jerked back lol (not too violently and not enough to break anything).

My favorite keyboard to date. Each key can be customized to activate at a certain depth. You can customize RGB infinitely. I have a few profiles set up for productivity, and others for gaming. Pretty slick. It better be, look at the price!

I chose this keyboard because of the screen, the linear keys and the fully adjustable RGB. I wish it had slightly more for media controls, but I get that they wanted it to look as sleek as possible. The linear keys are somewhat disappointing as they are just as loud as mechanical switches as far as I can tell. They do feel really smooth though and I have to say that typing this is very enjoyable despite the noise. I like the feel of the wrist rest as well and the magnetic attachment is a really nice touch. There is also a nice LED outline around the passthrough USB port which I can't see unless I lean forward to look for it which is absolutely brilliant design. Speaking of the USB passthrough though, the wire for this keyboard is HUGE. It's my first passthrough keyboard to idk if maybe they all have wires this large, but honestly it seem excessive to me. The LED screen is a nice touch and was the main selling point to me. I didn't want the hassle of incorporating a screen into my tower, and this is a super convenient work around. The Steelseries Engine software is fairly easy to use even if it tries to sell me things sometimes which is annoying. I have the screen set to cycle between displaying GPU load & clock, CPU load & clock, and CPU & GPU temps on three different pages.
TL;DR Despite my slight complaints about what I wanted out of this keyboard, it really is a quality product and I do recommend it.

If I could get this exact keyboard in a wireless model, I would be in heaven! Everything about this board is amazing. They keypresses are smooth and quiet, with zero noise actuation: the only real music this makes while typing are the keys themselves "bottoming-out" like any keyboard will do. I love the widely customizable RGB options, too!

name: Asus ROG Strix Scope II 96 RGB Wireless/Bluetooth/Wired Gaming Keyboard
comments: Looks great, very solid and lovely to use. Superb understated RBG.
really nice keyboard to type on and being 96 but still having numpad while compact is best of both worlds for me
Asus have outdone themselves.

name: Razer Ornata V3 X RGB Wired Gaming Keyboard
comments: Meh, not great, I have this problem with since day one where when I click caps lock it sometimes does not turn on, or turns off num lock or does both. Same thing for Num lock, I click on it, it turns caps lock off or ON, It's weird. Other than that spacebar is a bit flimsy. Bloatware still horrible, synapse is really annoying.
Spill resistant and low profile, awesome but its not pink
Great for the price, it looks amazing and has no issues. The software is easy to use for the colors and stuff.

name: Corsair K100 RGB Wired Gaming Keyboard
comments: Very responsive keyboard. The Optical switches feel a bit weird initially, but I did get used to it quickly. The lack of Linux support for RGB control (or at least, as far as I know) is a bit annoying

Needed a new Corsair keyboard because the last one's LEDs were turning yellow.
Still wanted a USB passthrough, and the additional macro keys are a nice touch.
Icue software is trash and doesn't work half the time, but keyboard is mid overall and sounds just as mid honestly is Corsair enough said...
The key presses register quick and the actuation point is basically zero. You touch it it goes. I haven't found much use of the iCUE wheel YET. It looks absolutely gorgeous as well.

The keyboard is very clickety clackity (that's a plus for me), and super easy to type on. My only gripe is my fingers are heavy and that when they rest on the keys I can inadvertently press a key. This is noticeable when playing League where I can sometimes press Q by mistake. While this is not an issue indicative of poor manufacture, I warrant it a personal issue of enough annoyance to give it 4 stars. Smaller hands will probably not have this issue. I'm a chef and wear size extra large disposable gloves in the kitchen, if this helps someone make the decision to buy it or not.
Great KB.

Really nice keyboard. The wristwrest is really comfortable, the rgb looks amazing, it feels nice to type on and game on. The wheel is surprisingly useful and so are the media keys. The only con is the ICUE software which can be *** at times.
Great feel on key press.
Very pricey but you notice the extra quality.
The font is a little sci-fi and I haven't found much use for the control wheel but lots of options for lighting and the keys feel great.

name: Dell KB216 Wired Slim Keyboard
comments: Wires are super annoying. At least it's low profile.

name: Logitech G915 Lightspeed RGB Wireless Gaming Keyboard
comments: This is an excellent keyboard. Despite its wireless capabilities, I always just use it wired, but it's nice to be able to unplug it if I want to. I have the clicky version, and I enjoy typing on it. I don't know how much others enjoy hearing me type on it, though. Having a numpad is a must for me personally, so I appreciate that this is a full size keyboard. The macro buttons are also nice, though I have limited uses for them other than creating a hotkey for Game Bar screenshots.
Feels nice, makes a click sound I like, but not annoyingly loud

Pros: Slim, easy to keep clean, simple RGB settings, and performs well.
Cons: None.

Has configurable G-keys with 3 configs you can switch between on the keyboard itself, also a key for disabling a key temporarily if you have any troubles, which really comes in handy. Nice lighting, and has different brightnesses. The wireless connection is very bad, however, so I use the cable included, and the keys easily fade away showing just the light from beneath, didn't last a single month. But it was only the S and D key for me due to sliding over them a lot when gaming.
I love it, i was previously using a G512 however when i had some issues Logitech just sent me this.
An overall great keyboard with consistent key presses.
Best keyboard I ever used.
I love the tactile feel of this keyboard. Admittedly, it's overpriced.
i lost my r key

Expensive, but worth it. Keys are much better than my Romer-G switches on my G910. Didn't go for clicky or linear because I don't want an obtrusively loud keyboard, and I use my keyboard for typing long papers, respectively. Battery life is amazing, even with the lights on. My only gripe is that there is a bit of key wobble, but it is fine by me.

name: Wooting Two HE RGB Wired Gaming Keyboard
comments: Best keyboard I've own, period. Didn't want to mess with custom keyboards so this was very close to perfection out of the box. I just changed the keycaps to some PBT ones since they didn't offer the PBT default ones for my language.

The best gaming keyboard I've ever had the pleasure of using. Its easily modible and can be moved into different cases.
Mine is currently in a Tofu 60 Redux.
Ive used the Lekker Linear60 (Green), 50G Springs, Lekker Linear45 (Yellow) , Jades, and the Stickyrice. I have to say the sticky rice are an incredible upgrade.
Love the sound and speed.

The best keyboard I've ever owned. The constant quality of life updates really make it shine and the analog Lekker switches are absolutely fantastic if you want to play GTA or any open world game with driving and want the controller feel this is the way to go

My long struggle to replace an old Corsair K70 eventually found this. I often find myself under hitting the spacebar, and the wooting's ability to make individual keys super sensitive really helped with that.
It's also an incredibly fast board in general with tachyon mode and rapid trigger, excellent for getting those 360 Awp quickswitch no-scopes in CS.

name: Razer DeathStalker V2 Pro RGB Bluetooth/Wireless/Wired Gaming Keyboard
Logitech G413 SE Wired Gaming Keyboard
comments: It's big. It's heavy. It's loud. And it does not chug tonnes of petrol!

Keys feel good, looks extremely clean in all aspects: keys, back lighting, aluminum backbone.
Lacking a volume button (personal preference) and some way to reduce/disable lights for night time.

Good keyboard, although fairly loud. Clicky and clacky all the way home but the build quality is good and lights are non-invasive. I bought renewed on Amazon and have no complaints about that process.

Fantastic keyboard for the price. He was looking at some cheaper ones, saying that they are just keyboards. However, I explained that a keyboard (and mouse) are the two most used computer items and to get something that is quality. He used my G513 already, and wanted something similar but not as expensive. They had this on display at the MC store and he was hooked!

The brown switches offer a gentle, but not very "clicky" response. Each key is individually lit, so I wish there was customization through the G HUB software (lighting levels, responsive keys, etc.) because sometimes the settings of key-lit settings don't stick after reboots/power-cycles. However, for now it seems to be a pretty simple, functional, and useful keyboard.

name: Logitech G915 TKL RGB Wireless/Bluetooth/Wired Gaming Keyboard
comments: The brown/tactile feels better than the red/linear version and not any louder. Works with the new Windows 11 Dynamic Lighting feature: this changes your keyboard and mouse lights to match your PC theme automatically, and one of the benefits is you get real cool built-in colour effects and animations while playing for example Borderlands 3 or Tiny Tina's Wonderlands (with no setup required).

Love how the buttons feel as I'm typing. I prefer smaller keyboards, and this one fits the bill. Nicest keyboard I've ever owned. Still confused as to why it's Micro-USB instead of USB-C, but that's a small personal gripe.
Great mechanical keyboard. I got the tactile one and very happy with it. Long battery life, nice lighting and typing.

Decent wireless mechanical keyboard - mostly got it for the physical volume scroll and other dedicated media keys. Apart from that, I prefer my Keychron K2 w/ brown switches to this in every way shape and form. Really annoying that a keyboard from 2020 does not charge via USB-C when the rest of Logitech's Lightspeed series mice had already gone to USB-C by that point. Also annoying that you can't sync multiple Lightspeed devices (like the G502 mouse) to the same dongle.
great keyboard that i got renewed off of amazon that worked fine. saying you can get this thing for 100 dollars off, its a steal.
Good.
One of the best wireless keyboards out there, in terms of response time, battery life and overall comfort of typing this keyboard is amazing. These Logitech LightSpeed tech is superb.

Without a doubt the nicest keyboard I've ever owned, and I bought it used for a massive discount. Between the low-profile keys, the RGB backlighting, and the navy blue anodizing of the casing, the aesthetics are fantastic. The volume scroller is a great feature that I really appreciate.
I can't really detect the tactile 'bump' of the keys unless I'm really feeling for it, but that's probably just because I have sausage fingers. Also, for some reason my F1 key likes to get stuck on yellow; I don't know whether that's by design or just from previous use, but it just takes that one key a little while to get with the program. Not worth taking off a star in my opinion, just putting it out there.
The one problem I have with it is that it's USB-micro charging. It's not a huge problem to have an additional charging cable tucked behind my monitor, it just would have been nice to have USB-C.
Good quality, good battery life and wireless.

This is the first high end keyboard I’ve ever owned, so I can’t really compare it to anything else. Despite this, I really enjoy this keyboard. It’s nice and compact thanks to being TKL. The low profile mechanical switches look sleek and feel nice. The build quality of the keyboard is excellent, being entirely aluminum. It’s battery life is excellent

name: Razer BlackWidow V3 RGB Wired Gaming Keyboard
comments: Satisfiying keyboard, not for everyone if u dont like the noise it makes. but i enjoy the sound. Clickish
had it from my laptop!! love the tkl, so clicky and works so well<3

A great keyboard with a good weight (i like the feel and weight of metal, which this has a nice bit of both) the keys feel nice, the size is great, and i actually dont mind the razer synapse software. It has more options then i expected, but i still uninstalled it and went with SignalRGB for global rgb compatibility.
Its very loud but very good
Chroma RGB and keyboard sounds and feels great.
Amazing keyboard

name: Logitech G213 PRODIGY RGB Wired Gaming Keyboard
comments: nice membranes. only flaw is that you can't paint each key in different colour
It's a cheap, heavy, large keyboard, but it feels nice when typing.

I don't know many things about keyboards but this one seems to do what I needed. I wanted a Ten Key one and I think it will fine for me with gaming and productivity for a first keyboard. 33€ during Black Friday.
Classic wired keyboard with illumination.
good keyboard, in between membrane and mechanical keyboard which is good for me coming of a laptop keyboard. Good RGB control, only has five zones but for 50 bucks it's pretty good.
Membrane keyboard. Very few rgb zones. It has dedicated media controls, which is why I’m giving it three stars.
Very good non-mechanical gaming keyboard with RGB. I got it on sale.
Not perfect but it does the job until I get a mechanical one

Nice Logitech keyboard. I didn't put any thought into it, just bought the cheapest Logitech. It only has 5 zones for RGB lighting but like I said, I'm an adult so I don't care about unicorn vomit. I have it set to white so I can see the keys in the dark and I'm all set.
Good board for the price.

name: SteelSeries Apex Pro Mini RGB Wired Gaming Keyboard
Logitech G715 RGB Wired/Wireless/Bluetooth Gaming Keyboard
comments: keyboard is fantastic but logitech g hub is the worst software ever

name: Razer BlackWidow V4 Pro 75% RGB Wireless/Bluetooth Mini Keyboard
Logitech G512 CARBON RGB Wired Gaming Keyboard
comments: Nice typing feel with not too much noise imo.

The keyboard really is quite good. I got tactile switches so it wouldn't wake people at night and as I will also use it for work. The RGB looks nice, logitech app is good and the brushed aluminium plate looks great.

Took me a while to settle on a keyboard. Was going to go with a K915 (also Logitech) but decided it wasn't worth the extra $150. Really nice, professional keyboard that doesn't scream GAMER. Absolutely love the gunmetal finish.
I'm no keyboard enthusiast but imo, this is a great keyboard with a nice feel and sound. The gunmetal finish on the top looks good and the RGB is controlled by the Logitech G software. Not bad at all
I mean it's Logitech, so it's good.

name: SteelSeries Apex 3 RGB Wired Gaming Keyboard
comments: Got it for $50 CAD, is built well and rgb is nice

I love so many things about this keyboard. I like the noise the keys make. The RGB is not the most customisable in the world, but I really like what is there. I like the multimedia buttons - it has a volume wheel and a single button that can pause/play music. That same button can also skip a song and go back a song. I do not use those functions very regularly, but it is good they are there. For some reason, I really like the Escape key. It feels good to look at and press. For anywhere between $35-50, I highly recommend this keyboard.
Coll keyboard, feels good. Nice RGB customization.
I got for $35 and I can't complain about it. I like that it comes with the palm rests for this price, can't beat it. RBG is great and I like the control buttons and scroll.
it is ok it is like a office keyboard with nice lights
easy to use
Very quiet and the switched feel nice. But I'm a keyboard noob, so you shouldn't take my advice. RGB control is intuitive.
Feels good for a budget membrane keyboard. RGB is smooth. Software had some issues for a while and kept closing but it seems to be fixed now.
From my previous setup, I plan to upgrade to a Corsair K70 TKL Champion Series w/ red switches ASAP. It's a good keyboard though for what, $30? Definitely the best membrane keyboard I've ever used.
Got it as a bundle with the Rival 3. It works great!

name: Redragon DEVARAIAS K556 RGB Wired Gaming Keyboard
comments: after coming from a laptop with shallow keys this keyboard is fantastic it sounds great and comes with a numpad and all the utility buttons the average user needs

I had actually bought the DHARMA, the same but TKL, but it wasn't available on here so I just picked this one for the build since it's functionally the same. A nice sturdy board. Coming from a laptop, the red keys are nice and not as loud as other switches.

This is a really good keyboard for the price. I have had this thing for about 3 years and it is awesome. The only gripe i have about it is that it is a little loud and my escape key requires you to press it multiple time for it to work, however it just recently started this. But it does come with 8 extra switches to swap out I have already use 5 of them and tried to change the escape key, but nothing is fixing it. So i think is is a circuit board issue. Besides that, this is an amazing keyboard that is super responsive, comes with 15 color presets (so you dont even have to install the software to change it, which is a huge plus) and is certainly a solid pick for anyone on a budget.
nice sounding board with enough keys for games like Minecraft

This is one of the used parts I salvaged from my previous build. I made the purchase four years ago with the assumption that it should be more than adequate for my future builds. Keyboard works great still and I really enjoy the brown switches.
Fantastic mechanical keyboard. Typing with it is a dream compared to membranes. Color schemes are plentiful, and the LEDs are bright. Can be used as a bludgeoning-type weapon in a pinch.

A great entry level mechanical keyboard; The outemu browns feel indistinguishable from real cherry switches (though they sound a bit different) and the keycaps feel nice. It's a bit bulky but if you're buying a full 104 key board you're probably not concerned about that. RGB is good and the ability to control it without software is a nice touch, as are the function keys and win lock.
Affordable mechanical keyboard. Have had trouble with getting the proper driver for this keyboard but honestly it doesn't matter for me. Works well and being cheaper, its perfect for my first build

For the price, this keyboard is pretty great. They keyboard is fairly heavy, so it's rare that you'd see any sort of keyboard sliding or even moving of that sort unless you were purposefully moving it. This model came with Outemu brown switches, which I personally really enjoy the feel of. It's a great middle of the road between having the audible response of a mechanical keyboard while also not waking up the entire neighborhood with your typing.
As far as RGB goes, while the LEDs are individual, it works by presets. This means that if you had any custom preset option for lighting that you had in mind, you're out of luck on that end. However though, the lights are quite vibrant and unless you're going for a super unique customized look, the presets that come on the keyboard should more than suffice. If you have the money to, switch out the keycaps with the HyperX PBT pudding keycaps, it's well worth it.

Good solid mechanical keyboard. Brown switches that make typing very smooth. A bit louder than cheap keyboards that I was used to. Lots of lighting effects and options which are easily configured with no need for extra software. Simply hold function and press specific keys to change lighting effects, color, and brightness.

name: Logitech Wireless Combo MK270 Wireless Standard Keyboard With Optical Mouse
comments: You get what you get for the price ig. It is a really crappy keyboard tho, would reccomend just spending more money.
Does what I need it to, feels good, just wish it had built in battery that I could charge. Very long battery life if you turn it off when not using though.

It's a cheap wireless mouse/keyboard combo and the keyboard is bendy enough to prove it.
However, this is a great purchase. The keyboard and mouse work off the same one USB connector, neither have had any issues with communication with the computer, both are energy efficient and I've yet to need to replace the batteries.
Had I not been insistent on getting a "gaming mouse" I've yet to need for actual gaming, I would have bought this for my own computer as well. That said, it does feel weird using the mouse because it's smaller but "taller" than my own gaming mouse but that's a "me" issue.
I would definitely buy this for any new computer builds I do.
It's a keyboard and a mouse. But Logitech is great
A nice basic keyboard to do what you need on. It'll work as a replicant or a good first keyboard to fit your needs.
The mouse and keyboard came as a set for Logitech and work just fine productivity purposes and the wireless functionality keeps my desk clean.
My mouse pad is my couch. These work great. I'm just annoyed it doesn't have a low battery light, so I don't need to guess at the reason it got flaky.
Quite sturdy and light. Key presses feel good as well!

Seems to be hard to find a normal keyboard nowadays in any offline store - this one was closest to a normal layout (F-key row is oddly small and no right winkey(???)) but it was wireless. $25 and feels like it. I had to run a USB extension because the dongle would drop signal if it is more than 1' away from the keyboard. The mouse it comes with feels like a toy, It felt so light that a sneeze could send it off my desk.
Nice little ergonomic wireless combo that's comfortable to use.

name: SteelSeries Apex Pro TKL (2023) RGB Wired Gaming Keyboard
SteelSeries Apex Pro Gen 3 RGB Wired/Wireless/Bluetooth Gaming Keyboard
Corsair K70 Wired Gaming Keyboard
comments: This keyboard is fantastic. I love the tactile feel of the cherry mx blues and with the ICUE software I am able to have some awesome looking effects. The only downside to this keyboard is it's definitely not waterproof but it was my fault lol

Typing on mine right now. MX Blues are my favorite and the red lighting is nice. I prefer red because it doesnt sting my eyes in the dark. Lighting settings are great with a custom profile built in and 4 levels of light from the keys. Included keycap puller works great. Best of all this keyboard has super solid construction. Metal plate holding all the surface. Thick braided cable and the USB pass through is super nice. Corsair has my business for life on the keyboard side of things if they can maintain this level of function and quality. Highly recommend

You ever been working late at night in the next room and are trying to be quiet so the wife can sleep? This is the keyboard for you! (sarcasm!!!) I've used MX Blues before and know how loud the click is. If you still like the tactile feel, but don't want the click, opt for browns. The red LED has three brightness levels (four, if you count off), though I usually keep mine on the lowest setting. There is a Windows key lock, and an FPS lighting profile button that just illuminates the arrow keys, number keys from 1-6, and WASD (though I believe you can change what keys are illuminated). The media keys are awesome. There is a large mute button, next to a steel or aluminum textured volume roller (definite extra points for this), there is also a (stop, previous song, play/pause, next song) button row right above the numpad. Dedicated media keys are always a plus, especially if they feel good and work right, as these do both. The included wrist rest is nice, and it is the same length all the way across, so perfect for typing. There are both front and rear pop-out feet that are rubberized when closed and opened.
It also comes with 10 replacement keys. These keys are textured red, and angled intelligently. It comes with 1-6 in red with rough bumpy texture, with number 1 being angled to the right, and number 6 being angled to the left. It also comes with WASD in red, bumpy texture. The A is angled to the right, and the D is angled to the left. S is flat, and W is angled towards you. Clearly these replacements are for FPS. The key puller tool that it comes with is the cheap black plastic ring claw one, the claw teeth aren't long enough, so you have to press down a couple of times to get it to grab. A nicer wire one would have been appreciated.
Time for my only gripes with this keyboard: 1. There is only one USB pass-through and it is barely even adequate to charge a smart phone. 2. The sleeved cable which goes back about 3 feet before splitting into two USB cables is much too thick, it is so thick it knocks stuff around on my desk if I have to slide my keyboard forward 3. The Corsair Gaming logo is tacky... it does honestly look like a tramp stamp, and since this is my professional keyboard, with the Logitech G910 Orion Spark being my gaming keyboard, it is definitely out of place. A classic Corsair Sails logo would be appreciated (which I've heard they've gone back to)
5/5 regardless, the keyboard is immaculate, and the design and included extras outweigh the little gripes here and there.

Great keyboard! as my first mechanical keyboard, this is perfect in every way! The aluminum body makes this keyboard feel premium, lights make it easy to see in the dark and makes the keyboard in my opinion look awesome, also has some useful media switches along with a windows key lock button and a button to select certain keys to light up. Definitively will recommend to others.

name: Corsair K70 CORE RGB Wired Gaming Keyboard
comments:
Tested it out for the first time in my local best buy and it was the only keyboard with keys I liked that weren't super loud or felt crumby. Got it as a gift for Christmas and was so excited to test it out.
The bad: At first I loved it, until I realized red linear switches are notorious for double key tapping. Had to go into windows settings and turn key repeat and delay all the way down (thanks to a short from MetaPCs for the fix) but it would still double press on occasion. That would make games with precise inputs (like helldivers 2) impossible. I was going to switch back to my cheapo cyberpower mechanical until recently, where I went into iCue and set the key depress delay to 5ms and it made it better. Sucks I had to do that but it's better now.
The good: Love the way the keys depress and it's super quiet and smooth. Made of very heavy materials and uses very thick and grippy rubber feet to keep it locked into place. Love the tactile knob that's programmable for different uses, I'm using it for volume control. The RGB is awesome and lots of different patterns and colors. The use of the iCue app makes everything super customizable of that's your thing. Me, I want a plug and play keyboard and only want to change cosmetics.
Overall, it would be a much better keyboard without linear switches or easier to find guides how to fix the double key presses. The amount of work I've put into it has made it better but gifting this to someone else without them knowing how much they need to customize it would ruin a friendship.

Nice feel and size. I am getting some double-clicking, which kinda sucks. You can change the double-click sensitivity in the iCUE software, which almost entirely fixes it for me. RGB-Customizable with several hardware memory profiles in the software.

name: Asceny One RGB Wired Mini Keyboard
Corsair K70 RGB PRO RGB Wired Gaming Keyboard
Logitech G915 Lightspeed RGB Wireless Gaming Keyboard
comments: Absolutely amazing KB. Bought used, and it looked brand new and functions as expected.

what can i say but holy **** is thing keyboard amazing, im typing with it now and am loving every moment of it, perfect key travel, satisfying click, very responsive buttons, beautiful rgb, absolutely everything you could ever ask for, makes gaming snappy and typing enjoyable
My first mechanical keyboard and I'm loving it so far. Battery life is great, and the RGB is as well. I could totally understand someone not wanting to buy this due to the price though.

Highly niche and highly expensive, but if you seriously want a wireless mechanical keyboard with clicky switches, then you'll know it's worth it by sheer dint of there being no other product that fits the description. The rest of the board—build quality, design, lighting, software, extra features—does match the price to the best degree it can, so Logitech did genuinely make a good product in the abstract and you're not just paying an exclusivity tax, but it's still a price you're only going to pay if you want this specific switch style without a permanent cord attached.
One specific thing I haven't heard mentioned in professional reviews much if at all, but that has quickly become my favorite thing about the board—I'm not sure what the low-profile design has to do with being wireless (if anything), but MX Blue-style feedback coupled with the key height and travel distance of a laptop keyboard is a typing and gaming dream. I was hitting better WPM numbers with this board than with any other I've ever owned within a day of getting it, and just by common sense my keypresses in-game are faster because I don't need to depress the key as far to actuate it. I've gained the faster response time and greater typing output that, say, an MX Red or MX Speed board would afford me without giving up any of the satisfying and reassuring Blue-style tactical feedback, and it's absolutely amazing.

name: SteelSeries Apex 7 TKL RGB Wired Gaming Keyboard
comments: Excellent keyboard with nice sounding keys (I got them in MX Cherry Red). The display on the top right of the keyboard is kinda useless, but still a good keyboard!!

One of the best keyboards I’ve ever had for their price. The screen is pretty mediocre. The software is really good. My biggest surprise is that the keyboard synchronized with another game I was playing, such as counter strike. The lights would show my ammo, bomb going off, and the screen would display my end of the round kd. Really amazing. I like the switches. Not too clicky, not too quiet.
-Sold on the RGB but the unsung heroes are the Red – Linear & Quiet mechanical keys.
Super nice typing experience. I had a K95 with Browns before this and I can confidently say these are better.
i love it, the sound and feel is amazing

tldr: this keyboard is good.
Actual review: Ok so I really like this keyboard. Mine has the Red switches and I'm a huge fan of how they feel. They go down smooth and typing with them is a nice experience. Gaming with them is great as well, i've never had a problem where a keypress is not detected or any issues with ghosting. The backspace key is SUPER easy to press. I had a crappy keyboard before this one and the backspace and enter keys sometimes just did not depress when I hit them. This one does not have that problem.
The screen is pretty cool. Despite what some might tell you it is NOT useless. In normal use I can have snazzy image on there as I don't see much use for the other apps, but for gaming I personally set it to monitor RAM usage, CPU usage and temps, and GPU usage and temps. It's very useful for that as while I do have a second monitor, OpenHardwareMonitor clogs up actually useful stuff on there like discord or spotify. I like monitoring this stuff in case there's a critical error or the like. It also lets you customize macros (which I have not yet found a use for) and the color scheme on the keyboard which is pretty frickin' sweet. The volume wheel is nice and a lot easier to use than the buttons most other keyboards have and the pause/play/skip/back/whatever button is nice as well. It fits in all the functionality and MFD control into a smaller package. overall, the screen IS a gimmick, but it is a welcome one in my world.
The font is very very nice. Some other keyboards have like stupid "gamer" fonts and highlighted WASD (looks awful even if you use WASD) and this font is very nice, readable, and looks sick with the RBG on. The keycaps are ABS, however, I do not mind this. Some others might tho. I do have one major gripe with the keycaps though: on these keys: - = [ ] ; ' , . / \ the main function, which is listed there, is ABOVE the shift functions which are _ + { } : " < > ? | respectively, and this is super annoying. I don't mind it on the number row for some reason but it's annoying on these. It's not enough to retract a star in my book however.
The wrist rest is very interesting. I'm not sure what it's made of, but it is definitely something hard, but for some reason it feels soft?? like you touch it and it's like a bedsheet or something but rigid. It's super weird and i love it! it's pleasing to wrest your wrists on and does its job well. The steelseries logo on the rest looks super nice as well.
I was originally skeptical of getting a TKL keyboard, but overall I am very happy with my choice. Even though I have never used the numberpad it was hard to let go of it...and then I saw the difference in price and never looked back. Seriously though, I'm happy I ditched it, I have a LOT more desk space (it's mind boggling how something that small can take up so much room) and I still get to keep the M keys and arrow keys in a good spot. I personally enjoy them there rather than all bunched up with no breathing room like in a laptop keyboard. Them, the F keys, the screen, the font, and the backlighting all give this keyboard a beautiful visual balance and it's honestly kind of a work of art. I'm beyond satisfied with my choice and would definitely recommend this keyboard to anyone.
Works amazingly well, buttery smooth switches. -1 star for rgb software not being the greatest.
can rickroll people. 5/5
Great for tight spaces (or small people like me), RGB customization on point, cool display USB passthrough for mouse is cool. Feels premium, especially the wrist-rest.
Great mechanical keyboard no ghosting, matte finish on the keys and steel-series engine 3 is great software. Only annoyance is that it doesn't save small image preset when software is closed.

name: Microsoft Natural Desktop 7000 Wireless Ergonomic Keyboard With Laser Mouse
HP HyperX Alloy Origins Core RGB Wired Gaming Keyboard
comments: Overall happy with this keyboard. Needs to be cleaned once every half a year or so, otherwise the keys don't register inputs unless you press on the key really hard. Can't complain though.
Great keycaps, good RGB and fantastic build quality.

Beautiful keyboard, as long as you get pudding keycaps. Switches feel great, sounds great, and is full metal. No flex at all. Only downside is the usb-c port is recessed into the keyboard so many cables do not work (there is an included cable that works)

Excellent keyboard, feels very sturdy/high quality build, and the keys are responsive with a satisfying clicking noise without being overbearingly loud. RGB is customisable per key in NGENUITY so you can have your WASD keys a different colour etc.
Got the pbt version, had to rma the first due to stuck keys, however now it works flawlessly.
A lot less clicky than my earlier Razer BlackWidow. Red switches give a nice feeling that's solid but doesn't feel non-existent when I tap.
Excellent TKL keyboard. The red switches and RGB are great. The build quality is among the best in its price category.
Overpriced; however, the build is very, VERY sturdy. Switches feel nice and are responsive
Great quality and RBG for the price. Red keys can be sorta annoying sometimes with how light they are ahah.

Very nice TKL mechanical keyboard. It has a clean and simple design that I think looks great. The HyperX Red switches are good I don't mind having ABS keycaps on a sub-$100 keyboard. No included wrist rest is a bummer but I bought a Grifiti one on Amazon that works well enough (beware: it reeks for the first few days). HyperX NGENUITY is lightweight and well designed, and controls the key mapping, RGB lighting, etc. This is a good option for an all-around pleasant experience.

name: MSI Vigor GK30 RGB Wired Gaming Keyboard
comments: Had it for 3 years by now. It's alright. Gave it 4 stars because there are better keyboards in the same price range.
This unfortunately is yet to be delivered, but my 17 yrs old Samsung Trution and 18 yr old HP mouse are doing well.

I thought I would get the matching MSI family keyboard for the RGB factor. On the leds is already burned out but I dont really care so much about that as much as the typeface they have used on the keys is very hard to read. I expect clear letter and symbols on a keyboard. This is not that great in that department. The 8 and the 9 are almost identical ad are 5 and 6. Ridiculous really as I working the accessibility space and my own keyboard is not that good in that category. With the weight of the keyboard I thought it would be more clicky but it is just ok in that department but nothing special.
works like any other keyboard and buttons feel great

name: Razer BlackWidow V4 75% RGB Wired Mini Keyboard
comments: While this board is not in my current setup, It was a very solid keyboard with hot-swap capability meaning I can use my gateron and kailh switches. While only the top-plate is aluminum, it still sounds nice with its pre-installed foam and factory tape mod. Also supports screw in stabilizers which I used but the stock plate-mounted ones are also pretty nice with minimal rattle. Even comes with a nice wrist rest.

name: Keychron V1 Max Bluetooth/Wireless/Wired/Wired Mini Keyboard
Logitech G915 X LIGHTSPEED RGB Wired/Wireless/Bluetooth Gaming Keyboard
Whirlwind FX Element V2 RGB Wired Gaming Keyboard
comments: Comes with a keycap puller. Sounds okay, but I'm wearing a headset anyways. Feel-wise it's nice, and the software that it works with is great for rgb control.

name: G.Skill KM360 Wired Standard Keyboard
comments: I'm not a mechanical keyboard enthusiast, so keep that in mind. The space bar is a different switch from every other key, slightly louder. The build quality is solid, but the font on the keyboard is inconsistent-letters are sometimes spaced badly or vary in thickness. There's a single white adjustable LED under each key, but that makes for nonuniform lighting under keys with longer words, like enter/shift if that bothers you. Or you could just turn the backlight off. No default play/pause audio or volume control or brightness control. However, Windows PowerToys solves that issue. But the main positive is the price, as of writing this it is under $50 on Amazon, which is incredible.

Amazing budget keyboard with cherry mx red switches. The only possible negatives to this thing in my mind are that it doesn't have any RGB or dedicated media controls. The white backlit LED looks great, though, and not having media controls is completely understandable at its price point for me. If you're looking for a budget mechanical keyboard and are a fan of cherry mx switches, this is simply the best there is.

I love this keyboard because it's a great build for the price, and feels really solid. There isn't any RGB, but frankly that wasn't something that I need and it the white backlight works with my current setup anyways.

Loving this keyboard so far. It looks really clean next to a white pc build. Only wish the fn (function) key could be used to raise/lower sound and volume. I'm not super crazy into keyboards so I can't really put any valuable input into how the switches and key caps feel, but they feel and sound nice to me.

name: Corsair K65 60% RGB Wired Mini Keyboard
comments: Sweet keyboard. Thing is durable too, I've taken it on quite a few trips and its survived. Easy as hell to clean, I don't even have to take the keycaps off, just blast canned air into it.

Amazing little keyboard. Feels amazing to use, very durable, and has tons of options for lighting with the iCUE software. I've never had a single issue with this keyboard over the past 9.5 months I've had this. Comes with an additional spacebar and esc keycap with a keycap remover. I would recommend buying a keycap remover off of Amazon for dirt cheap just for better durability and longevity, but it's up to you. Thanks again, Corsair!
Great keyboard that has an 8000hz pooling rate and has a very easy to use and overall good rgb software, would recommend for competitive gaming.

Great keyboard for the price, super fast response time and nearly no input delay. The rgb is great and Corsair icue was relatively easy to use. However this keyboard is so loud my parents hear me typing on it from downstairs.
Clicky and small :)

Comfortable keyboard to type on, well balanced red switches with good stabilisation. RGB is clear and vivid, with easy control through either iCUE or Signal RGB. Only gripes is that the chassis could be thinner or come with a wrist rest to mitigate wrists bending so much upwards.

I tried to hate this keyboard after I bought it. All the keyboard snobs scoff at these name brand boards and go on about boutique sellers. But so far I can't help but love it. I got the speed switches, since it was the only option at my local best buy (I think you need to buy direct from corsair for reds). They feel so good to press down on. Build quality is fine, the plastic chassis doesn't bother me, it is at least sturdy feeling plastic. I love the look of the lighting; it reflects off the white plate on top of the pcb and bathes the area around the keys in color. You can even change the rgb on the board via function keys without software open, in addition to saving profiles to the board. The sound of the keys doesn't bother me much, I added foam to dampen it a bit. It's a bit pricey for a small keyboard, but not by too much I don't think. I wouldn't buy this for productivity typing due to the nature of 60%, but for gaming and casual use it is great!
bussin

Loving it! I got the white one to match my build. Works great with the many ICUE designs. The slanted profile of the keycaps throws me off and the "silent" switches are a little loud but other than that, a great choice. They also include a keycap puller and extra space/esc keys.
it not a wireless keyboard, but still great, loving it

name: Keychron C3 Pro Wired Standard Keyboard
Razer Huntsman Mini RGB Wired Mini Keyboard
comments: its good because i have a small desk and its a 60%. i would have probably bought one that isnt clicky though.
The keyboard is a small 60% and I wanted to try that for the first time and I can't say I'm disappointed. It works very well and sounds great. Only issue is the software
Clicky switches are so satisfying, and very cool, along with the colorful keys, and its amazing compact form, I love this keyboard! If it was wireless, it would be 6 STARS, but still not bad!
My first introduction to 60%. I like it. Before the firmware update it crashed explorer.exe all the time.

Sturdy, light, comfy, looks great, it's easy to play / type on it while sitting in the lotus position. Absolutely nothing bad to mention. Clicky but fast optical switches are nice. USB cable is detachable, braided and long. There's metal plate between the keys and the main plastic body. The only beef I can see people having with it -- is having to use the Razer software package -- Razer Synapse. Though I've been using some variation of it for years and am not bothered by it. Unlike the large and heavy Black Widow X, there's no plastic squeaking when handling it. It's been around 6 months since I got it, to use with a different PC originally, and all the LEDs are working well.

I knew before building this PC I wanted a 60%. This keyboard recently came out, and it is a good starter board. Price is a little steep, but my friend let me use his employee discount, so I was able to get for a pretty good price.

name: Razer Ornata V3 RGB Wired Gaming Keyboard
comments: I like how it feels when I click on a key. Responsive, and it glows!

name: Corsair K100 AIR Wireless RGB Bluetooth/Wireless/Wired Gaming Keyboard

specs.Switch Type: Cherry MX Ultra Low Profile Tactile

comments:
not as crispy or short travel as I wanted (I'm a scissor switch girl I gotta admit) but the lighting and connectivity are much better than the chiclet style non-gamer keyboards I'm used to.
I hate iCUE and I am taking off 3 stars because of iCUE

name: Keychron K10 Pro QMK/VIA RGB Bluetooth/Wired Standard Keyboard
comments: Sturdy keyboard with great switches. Plenty of customizability (though I havent yet figured out how to program my own lights)

name: SteelSeries Apex Pro TKL RGB Wired Gaming Keyboard
comments: is good
Really solid keyboard, a joy to type of when in flow.
sounds a little funky, softwares a little funky, but its got good actuation and good material. wish there was more room between the key/used cherry profile.
Nice little TKL keyboard with plenty of configuration built-in. Installable-software is ok, but I don't use it.
This is the best keyboard I have ever had. The magnetic wrist rest is very comfortable and SteelSeries software is very user friendly. I love that I can change my keys actuation point.
fantastic feeling keyboard, but the adjustable switch are a set and forget thing and not worth the extra money, mini screen is cool but the software feels stone age
Feels great but the stabilizers have a little rattle. Nothing you cant fix though!
Great keyboard currently typing with it. I can adjust the actuation and it feels buttery smooth. Sounds nice as well.

had the apex 3 previously to save my money for the actual parts i wanted but after using that keyboard, i fell in love with steelseries. Once i had my upgrades i went all out and got this upgrade, and wow its completely over the top but i wouldnt change anything about it. the adjustable switches were the main reason i chose this one over any other of their keyboards and the durability is even better then i can imagine. Other then their steelseries engine software being hit or miss, especially if you want it running in the tray while gaming, i would stand by a steelseries product any day (granted im new and have only used razer and steelseries products its just my opinion!)

THE BEST KEYBOARD HANDS DOWN!
keys are buttery smooth and fast! actuation points are adjustable to your liking. Build quality is unmatched. I've had 8 keyboards in the past year and I finally found the one!

name: Razer Blackwidow V3 - Quartz RGB Wired Gaming Keyboard
comments: Love how the keyboard looks as pink is my favourite colour. RGB backlight is so cute as you can program it to any colour you like and has many different light effects.

I bought the black version instead, not the pink one, but PCP doesn't seem to have the black version. The keyboard is great, super clicky which is just the way I like it. The RGB software is kind of tricky to navigate if you're a first-timer like me, but other than that I really enjoy this keyboard.

name: Redragon S101 Wired Gaming Keyboard With Optical Mouse
comments: I've heard a lot of people rage about Redragon, but this keyboard has served me well, so no arguments here!

20 bucks for a mouse and 20 bucks for a keyboard. both have RGB colors for teens, so it was a no brainer. hope that they last a while. I usually buy more expensive I/O devices for me. but for a 9yr old I think this was a decent price for $39.99 for both Mouse and Keyboard. quality yet to be determined... if it survives a 9 yr. old gaming tantrum then we maybe golden. looking over the build quality and materials used, the keyboard looks ok, the mouse looks to me to be more fragile, but we will see.

I bought the WHITE version of this keyboard, but it feels great, has quiet keys (for those of us who tend to pound on the keys pretty hard) and the colors are vibrant and plentiful. I got this for around $40, so I can't complain about it at all. I really think it fits my build nicely - and it's the FIRST thing people notice after the case itself.

I guess you get what you pay for. Keys feel responsive and sturdy and the mouse is comfortable in your hand. However, both look very cheap and plastic-y. The RGB lighting is fine but controlling it is a pain. The keyboard RGB is controlled directly through key presses and it cycles through presets. Occasionally, it forgets which lighting preset you chose upon restarts, which is annoying. The mouse required software to change the RGB and that was extremely hard to find. The manuals were unhelpful and poorly translated and there was no model number provided for the mouse, leaving me to find the correct mouse software through a process of elimination (it's the M601RGB, by the way). Ultimately, both devices perform fine and the price is good for budgets if RGB isn't too important to you.

I actually loved both of the items that came in this package! The keyboard has been flawless the entire time I've owned it, a bonus being the wrist/palm rest, something I didn't have at all with my previous keyboard!
The mouse on the other hand... Well, I only got to use it briefly. It was an incredible mouse while I had it, but I ultimately gave it to my cousin for his build. It's serving him incredibly well, though, from what I've learned!

Yeah, sure it's a cheap feeling combo. But it works perfectly for a CASUAL GAMER. The mouse is a bit wonky and it's hard to find a good DPI setting but that's entirely subjective. RGB lighting is great and adjustable. 4 years daily use and not a single problem!

A nice cheap "RGB" keyboard with a red-light gaming mouse. The lights won't sync with your other components but there are enough pre-programmed options for the keyboard to find something close enough to whatever else you've got real RGB on.
The keyboard has some music-dedicated keys for pause/play, stop, previous and next track, but no dedicated volume button which could be an issue if you don't have a headset/speaker setup that you plan to use exclusively for adjusting the volume.

It's okay. I've been noticing issues with the keys not registering (purchased brand new) and the fact that the lights are continuously flashing. I'm sure there's a way to adjust the lights but I haven't figured it out yet. It's not intuitive on the board. Otherwise, it connects immediately to power.

I knew I was getting a cheap combo here, so I can look past the gummy button feel of the keyboard and lack of lighting control on the mouse. For the price, it looks decent and does the job well. Would recommend to a budget minded builder.

This is a fine starter combo. The kid wanted lights. This has lights. He can upgrade later with his own money if he decides he wants mechanical keys or upgraded mouse options. Good assortment of RGB effects on the keyboard (the mouse is only red). Nice long cables on both components, with the mouse being braided. Should hold up well. Nice powdered finish on the mouse for good grip.
One BIG complaint, the plastic casing around the USB connector is so chunk the keyboard and mouse can't occupy side-by-side USB ports on the rear IO panel.

name: Keychron K2 HE RGB Wireless/Bluetooth/Wired Standard Keyboard
Keychron V1 Max Bluetooth/Wireless/Wired/Wired Mini Keyboard
Logitech PRO X RGB Bluetooth/Wireless/Wired/Wired Gaming Keyboard
Asus ROG Azoth RGB Bluetooth/Wireless/Wired Mini Keyboard
